awd_titl_txt: CIF:Small:Collaborative Research: Energy-Aware Location Optimization in Emerging Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent years have witnessed an unprecedented emergence of new applications of wireless networks in different aspects of life. These new applications and their corresponding opportunities have improved the quality of life, provided economic growth, and facilitated the expansion of new businesses. Looking forward, several key defining aspects stand out for emerging wireless networks.  These include energy efficiency as a central feature enabling large-scale networks, prolonged network lifetime, and "green" (i.e., environmentally friendly) operation. Networks will also be highly heterogeneous in nature, consisting of nodes with different power, communication, and computational capabilities. Most wireless nodes, in order to fulfill their functions, will be endowed with sensing capabilities, connecting the physical world to the virtual information world. Networks are to remain connected with high reliability so that information from one node may be conveyed to another anywhere, and at any time. The emerging wireless networks are often considered to be multi-tiered, consisting of the nodes, their access points, and possibly higher-tiered gateways, and endowed with mobility.

The macro behavior of a wireless network (in terms of its overall sensing capability, energy efficiency, communication reliability, connectivity, and mobility) depends heavily on the micro placement/locations of its constituent nodes. This project explores the problem of energy-efficient node deployment in heterogeneous, multi-tiered, and mobile wireless networks, taking into account connectivity and autonomy. The innovative component exploits quantization theory, a seemingly unlikely candidate that is originally developed for signal compression, as a promising tool to address these challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There are many new applications of wireless networks with the goals of improving the quality of life, providing economic growth, and helping the expansion of new businesses. To support these new applications, energy efficiency is one of the central features as it enables large-scale networks, for example Internet of Things (IoT), prolonged network lifetime and green environmentally-friendly operation. The wireless networks of the future will also be highly heterogeneous in nature, consisting of physically-unidentical nodes with different powers, communication capabilities, computational powers, etc. Another feature is the inclusion of sensing capabilities, connecting the physical world to the virtual information world. Wireless networks will remain connected with high-reliability so that information from one node can be conveyed to another anywhere, any time. In addition, the emerging wireless networks are often considered to be multi-tiered, consisting of the nodes that can be mobile, their access points, and possibly, higher-tiered gateways.

We studied the problem of energy-efficient node deployment in heterogeneous, multi-tiered, and mobile wireless networks. We used quantization theory, a seemingly-unlikely candidate that is originally developed for signal compression, as a tool to address these challenges. More specifically, we developed new theoretical tools to establish quantization theory for heterogeneous reproduction points and used it to address the above challenges in wireless networks.

Specific technical accomplishments of this project can be summarized as:

1)     We studied the energy-efficient deployment of heterogeneous nodes in two-tier wireless sensor networks. We proposed a heterogeneous two-tier Lloyd-like algorithm to optimize the node deployment.

2)     We studied movement-efficient sensor deployment in networks with limited communication range. We designed both centralized and distributed algorithms to provide a flexible and explicit trade-off between sensing uncertainty and network lifetime.

3)     We constructed bounded-degree network topologies using only local information from neighboring nodes.

4)     We formulated the heterogeneous node deployment problem as a quantization problem with parameterized distortion measures and found the optimal solution for the one-dimensional uniform source.

5)     We studied the energy-efficient deployment of nodes in multi-hop wireless sensor networks and analyzed its optimal solution using tools from the source coding and rate-distortion theory. We designed energy-efficient deployment algorithms for multi-tier wireless sensor networks.

6)     We studied and analyzed energy-efficient deployments that jointly optimize more than one network characteristics and design requirements, i.e., heterogeneity, multitiered structure, and connectivity. We designed and analyzed deployment algorithms that maintain the connectivity of the network. We studied the trade-off between the power consumptions of different tiers of the network.

7)     We studied the optimal 3-D deployment of UAVs to minimize the average transmit power consumption of the users in a given target area. We investigated a UAV deployment in which each flying vehicle serves a set of users while carrying directional antennas. We studied the energy-efficient 3D wireless network deployment problems using directional antennas as a quantization problem and analyzed its optimal solution using tools from the source coding and rate-distortion theory.

8)     We studied and analyzed energy-efficient deployments that jointly optimize more than one network characteristics and design requirements, i.e., node deployment, cell partitioning, and data routing. We designed energy-efficient deployment algorithms for wireless sensor networks that take into account data routing.

9)     We studied the optimal deployment of coordinating UAVs in a cell-free communication network.
